This is not an Official GED® Practice Test. Although it will not count toward a scholarship for the GED® Test in Lee, Scott and Wise Counties or the city of Norton, VA, but it will give you a good idea of areas you may need to review.

The GED® Mathematics Test is divided into two parts, each containing 25 questions. The parts are equally weighted. On Part 1 of the test you may use the Casio fx-60 calculator to help you compute your answers. Use of the calculator is not permitted on Part 2 of the Mathematics Test.
 
 The following areas are tested on the Mathematics Test:
 ● Number Operations and Number Sense: 20% - 30%
 ● Measurement and Geometry: 20% - 30%
 ● Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability: 20% - 30%
 ● Algebra, Functions, and Patterns: 20% - 30%
 
 80% of the questions are multiple choice. The remaining 20% of the answers are calculated and entered in an alternate format into a standard grid or coordinate plane.
 
 A total of 90 minutes is allowed for the GED® Mathematics Test – 45 minutes for Part I and 45 minutes for Part II. A formula sheet, containing all the formulas that might be needed, is provided.

On the Math portion of the GED® Test, 20% of the questions will require you to calculate your own answer, record that answer on a grid, and fill in the corresponding circles on the grid. Both Parts I and II will have these items.
 
 When using the standard grid:
 ● Begin in any column that will allow your entire answer to be entered.
 ● Write your answer in the boxes on the top row, including decimals and the slash for a fraction bar.
 ● In the column beneath the number or symbol that you have written into your answer, fill in the bubble representing that number or symbol.
 ● Leave any unused column blank.
 
 Remember:
 ● Your answer sheet will be machine scored, so the circles must be filled in correctly.
 ● Mark only one circle in each column.
 ● No answer will be a negative number
 ● Mixed numbers must be gridded as improper fractions or decimals. For example, 1 ½ would be gridded as either 3/2 or 1.5.
 ● Decimal numbers may be entered with or without a leading zero. For example, either 0.5 or .5 would be an acceptable answer.

The GED® Science Test consists of 50 multiple choice questions from the following content areas:
 ● Earth and Space Science: 20%
 ● Life Science: 45%
 ● Physical Science(Physics and Chemistry): 35%
 
 The questions on the GED® Science Test require you to understand, interpret, or apply information that is provided on the test or that is learned through life experience. The information may be presented in a paragraph, chart, table, graph, map, or figure.
 
 The Science Test must be completed in 80 minutes.

The GED® Language Arts, Writing Test has two parts.
 
 Part I 
 
 This part contains 50 multiple choice questions that require you to revise and edit documents. There are three types of questions:
 ● Correction
 ● Revision
 ● Construction Shift
 
 The questions cover the following content areas:
 ● Organization: 15% – requiring restructuring paragraphs or ideas within paragraphs, identifying topic sentences, and creating unity and coherence in the document.
 ● Sentence Structure: 30% – Dealing with correcting sentence fragments, run–on sentences, comma splices, improper coordination and subordination, misplaced modifiers, and lack of parallel structure.
 ● Usage: 30% – Consisting of correcting errors in subject–verb agreement, verb tense, and pronoun reference.
 ● Mechanics: 25% – Including correcting errors in capitalization, punctuation, and spelling of possessives, contractions, and homonyms.
 
 This part of the GED® Language Arts, Writing Test has a time allowance of 75 minutes.
 
 Part II
 
 This part is the actual writing of an essay about an issue or subject of general interest. The essay topic assigned to you will require that you present you opinion, or explain your views about the topic. You will have 45 minutes to plan, write, and revise your essay. You will be given scrap paper for your notes, outline, and first draft. The GED® answer booklet has two pages of lined paper on which you will write your final essay.
 
 Scoring the Essay
 
 Two trained readers will score your essay on the basis of well–focused main points, clear organization , Specific development of ideas, control of sentence structure, grammar, word choice, and spelling.
 
 Each reader will score your essay on a 4–point scale, and the scores will be averaged to determine your final score. A minimum score of 2 is required on essay in order to pass the GED® Writing test.

June 24, 2002
 
 Jonathan Quinn
 Employment Director
 Capital City Gardening Services
 4120 Wisconsin Ave., NW
 Washington, DC 20016
 
 Dear Mr. Quinn:
 
 (A)
 
 (1) I would like to apply for the landscape supervisor position advertised in the Sunday, June 23rd edition of the Washington Post. (2) My work experience and education combined with your need for an experienced landscape supervisor have resulted in a relationship that would profit both parties. (3) In May, I graduated from Prince William Community College. (4) Graduating with an associate of arts degree in horticulture. (5) My concentration within the program was designing gardens and choosing the appropriate plants for particular soils and regions. (6) I have also had considerable supervising experience. (7) For several years, I have worked with a local company, Burke Nursery and Garden Center, and have been responsible for supervising the four members of the planting staff.
 
 (B)
 
 (8) Our community knows that Capital City Gardening Services is a company that does excellent work and strives hard to meet the demands of its clients. (9) As my references will attest, I am a diligent worker and have the respect of both my coworkers and my customers. (10) I will be, as a landscape supervisor at your firm, able to put to use the skills and knowledge that I have obtained from my professional career and education. (11) I have included a copy of my resume, which details my principal interests education, and past work experience. (12) I have also included photographs of the landscape projects I havesupervised as well as drawings of proposed projects.
 
 (C)
 
 (13) I am excited about the opportunities and many challenges that this position would provide. (14) Thank you for your consideration, and I look forward to hearing from you.
 
 Sincerely,
 
 Patrick Jones
 
 Patrick Jones
 1219 Cedar Lane
 Manassas, VA 20109

The Language Arts Reading Test is the shortest of the GED® Tests. It has 40 multiple choice questions that measure ability to comprehend and interpret workplace and academic reading selections and to apply those interpretations to new contexts. The questions ask you to understand, analyze, and synthesize information that you are given in the reading selections.
 
 Literary texts make up 75% of the Language Arts Reading Test and include at least one selection from each of the following areas:
 ● Poetry
 ● Drama
 ● Prose fiction before 1920
 ● Prose fiction before 1920 and 1960
 ● Prose fiction after 1960
 
 Nonfiction texts make up the remaining 25% of the test and include two nonfiction selections from any two of the following categories:
 ● Nonfiction prose
 ● Critical review of visual and performing arts
 ● Workplace and community documents
 
 The length of the reading passages ranges from 200 to 400 words. Poetry selections are from 8 to 25 lines. A purpose question appears in bold type before each reading selection. That question is not to be answered, but is designed to help you focus and give purpose for reading the text. Each reading selection is followed by 4 to 8 questions.

How Shall Employees Conduct Themselves?
 
 Guidelines for Conducting Business with Those outside Our Company
 
 Our employees are the most effective advertisement of our values, beliefs, and abilities. Always keep in mind that when you are acting in your capacity as our employee, you are contributing materially to the public image and the ultimate success of this company.
 
 (5) Gifts for Influence
 
 No payment or gift of money, goods, or services should be given or received to influence government or business decisions. Accurate and complete records for all accounts will be strictly monitored for everyone's protection.
 
 If it becomes apparent to you in the course of the performance of your business responsibilities that a (10) payment of some kind is expected by your business associate, please contact your division president.
 
 Conflict of Interest
 
 A conflict of interest can be described as a situation where a person has a vested interest in two areas of the business world that may give him or her an unfair advantage in business dealings. Our employees should be sensitive to any relationship that creates such a relationship –– or even (15) creates the appearance of such a relationship.
 
 Keep these rules in mind:
 ● Throughout your employment period, be vigilant about potential conflicts of interest between this company's interests and your personal or immediate family's interests.
 ● Don't use your position with this company to obtain a personal benefit of any kind.
 (20) ● Avoid any action or relationship that creates, or even creates the appearance of, a conflict of interest. For example, having an interest in a nonpublic company that competes or does business with our company or any of its affiliates might create the appearance of a conflict of interest and might prompt accusations and / or an investigations.
 
 Disclosure
 
 (25) This company respects your privacy, as well as your right to conduct your personal affairs without interference; however, you must make prompt, complete, and continuing disclosure of all facts relating to any factual or potential conflict of interest.
 
 Investigations
 
 Inquiries or investigations may be undertaken at this company's direction by its attorneys, (30) investigators, internal auditors, or independent public accountants. Employees should regard this vigilance as the company's commitment not only to fair competition but also to the protection of its employees. Your cooperation is needed for your protection as well as that of this company, and it is a condition of your employment.
 
 This exceprt is a composite of information from several business documents.

The GED® Social Studies Test contains 50 multiple choice questions from the following content areas:
 ● US History: 25%
 ● World History: 15%
 ● Geography: 15%
 ● Civics and Government: 25%
 ● Economics: 20%
 
 Most of the questions are based on written texts of one or more paragraphs, maps, diagrams, charts, tables, photographs, and cartoons. A total of 70 minutes is allowed to complete the GED® Social Studies Test.

The history of the world is filled with stories of people migrating. Migration is the movement of people from one place to another as they seek a new home. Famine, overpopulation, limited resources, war, and religious and political persecution "push" immigrants to new places.
 
 Millions have migrated to North America since the 1600s. Spanish, French, English, and Dutch immigrants were the first European settlers to establish permanent colonies. They settled in lands originally populated by people from Asia. Many people from Africa were driven from their homes at this time to be enslaved to work in colonies in the Americas.
 
 Throughout the 1800s, immigrants looking for employment came to North America from Japan, China, and southeastern Europe. In the 1970s and 1980s, Southeast Asians, Latin Americans, and Caribbeans migrated to North America. Many of these immigrants fled from war-torn countries, political persecution, and economic difficulties.

The Tests of General Educational Development (GED®) are recognized internationally. They are designed to measure major academic skills and knowledge in the core content areas that are learned during the four years of high school. The GED® credential certifies that an adult who has passed the five tests of the GED® has mastered subject matter, knowledge, and skills associated with high school completion. The GED® Tests battery includes a test in each of the following subject area tests:

 ● Language Arts, Writing
 ● Language Arts, Reading
 ● Social Studies
 ● Science
 ● Mathematics
How are the GED® Tests Scored?

The GED Testing Service® has established that a passing score on the GED® Test is a total score of 2250 for the five-test battery. This is an average of 450 with no single test score falling below 410. If any test score falls below 410, the test for that subject must be retaken to achieve a passing score.
A New GED® Test is Coming in 2014

The GED® Tests battery is revised and updated about every ten years. On January 1, 2014, a new GED® Test is scheduled to replace the current version. This new test will be vastly different from today’s test. It will be computer based with no pencil and paper version available, and the content of the test will be even more challenging.\n \n The bad news about the updated test is that any incomplete scores on the current version of the test will be discarded. That means that folks who took parts of the GED® test before 2014, but did not complete all the subjects and those who took the entire test but had some failing (below 410) scores, will be required to start all over again with the new test. The bottom line is this: If you do not obtain a GED® credential before Jan 1, 2014, you will be required to take the entire battery of the 2014 test.
